title: A Winter Storm in Changthang | Living with the Changpas of Ladakh - 4/6
description:
The Changpas have a complicated relationship with snowfall. They need good winter snow for the grass to grow well during the summers. But too much snowfall can create  trouble for them by burying the grass necessary for the survival of their animals.

A winter storm is the worst nightmare for the Changpas. And on the 3rd week of my living with the Changpas a winter storm is exactly what we got.

title: A Shepherd's Journey (with English Subtitles)
description:
This short film follows Narender Kaith, a Gaddi shepherd from the Kaobil village in the Shimla district of Himachal Pradesh. Every year he and his fellow Gaddis take a herd of around 1500 sheep and goats across the Bhabha pass from the Kinnaur region of Himachal Pradesh to Spiti. This video is about his life, his journey and the difficulties faced along the way.

I spent about 40 days travelling with the shepherds to make this video. Meeting Narender in the Bhabha valley was a completely random coincidence and I thank my lucky stars for that meeting. We were not that well acquainted on our onward journey from the Bhabha Valley to the Pin Valley. I was camping a bit away from the shepherds and cooking my own food. But we became much closer on the return journey and I was soon eating, sleeping and living in their camps. I was following truly in the footsteps of the nomads!

title: A Winter's Day in Changthang | Living with the Changpas of Ladakh - 2/6
description:
The changpas are a tribe of semi-nomadic people who live in Changthang, the high altitude plains of Ladakh and northern Tibet. Crops do not grow at these high altitudes, so the Changpas survive by raising goats and yaks. It is a hard life as they spend almost every moment days taking care of their animals and processing their produce. 


In this episode we will see what a typical day of a Changpa is like during the winters. Everything from their activities at home, in the village and out in the plains with their animals.

I was very hesitant to travel anywhere during this pandemic. The last thing I wanted was to be an unwitting carrier and spread the virus to such remote places. So I tried to be as careful as possible and got permission from the concerned authorities as well as the local people before traveling anywhere. A lot of gratitude to all my friends who helped me on this trip.

title: My Self-Isolation in Ladakh | A Trip to Matho Phu
description:
I was at the Matho Nagrang on festival on the 9th of March when news first broke out of a coronavirus infection in Ladakh. Two people returning from Iran tested positive for the virus and that put all of Ladakh into high alert.

The authorities moved quickly. The infected people and their whole village was put under quarantine immediately.  People started wearing masks everywhere. Even the very popular Matho Nargrang festival hardly had any visitors after the news broke out. The local administration even stopped issuing inner line permits to prevent the virus from spreading to the remote villages of Ladakh.

All this put me in a dilemma on whether to stay back or leave. I was in the process of making a short film about the Matho Nagrang festival and there was a ceremony on April 2nd which I was keen on covering. Moreover, the sparsely populated villages of Ladakh should be safer from the virus than the crowded cities of the plains. But I also had aging parents at home to think about. So I decided to stay back in Ladakh till the ceremony and head home immediately after that.

I booked my tickets for April 4th and headed to the mountains behind the Matho village to camp and self isolate myself from the virus. It was the best way to protect myself and also people with whom I was staying with in Leh.

I spent 6 nights camping in the mountains. I could have stayed longer but I was running low on fuel and also was anxious for some news from home. So I went down towards the village and the news I heard from my family and friends about the virus was not very encouraging. So I returned back to Leh the next morning and flew out on the 24’th of March.

title: Ladakh - A Time lapse Journey
description:
With India in Motion, my goal is to showcase the incredible beauty of India through time lapse videos.

Here is the first instalment towards fulfilling that goal. A time lapse showcase of Ladakh. I spent 3 months in Ladakh (6 weeks in Autumn and 6 weeks in the Winter) shooting these videos.

I do this on a shoe string budget. Spending around 300 Rupees (~5$) a day. In Autumn, I traveled around Ladakh on my motorbike and in the Winter I hiked and hitchhiked my way through this wonderful land. It was a lot of fun!. I camp a lot, both to minimize costs and to be at the right location at the right time, and stay in village homestays wherever I can. The warmth and generosity of the Ladakhi hospitality is an inspiration for all of us to emulate.

title: Traditional Horse Herding in Pin Valley/Spiti | Story of Todnam - 5/6
description:
The Chamurti is a small mountain pony almost exclusively found in Pin Valley. Also known as the Spiti Pony, it is one of the 6 recognised horse breeds of India. What makes the Chamurti  special is that it is one of the few natural “pacers” in the horse world. It trots side to side on its laterals rather than diagonals enabling the rider to sit comfortably for hours at a time.

Almost every family in Pin Valley is involved in the Chamurti business. The villagers work together as a community to raise these horses in typical Pin valley fashion. 

#Chamuri #Spiti

title: Bonang - The 12 year festival | Kinnaur | Nesang and Moorang Villages
description:
The Bonang festival in Nesang happens every 12 years when Chandika Devi, residing in the Moorang village is taken on a pilgrimage to her ancestral home in the mountains above the Ropa valley.

Chabdika Devi is joined by the Ormic Shu Devta from the Moorang village and the Shangche Kyum and Mela Kyum Devtas from the Nesang village.

Together they go to the Pangrang Mata temple above the Nesang village. Where the priests perform sacred rituals which open a portal to the Ropa Valley across the Sutlej river.

description:
Chandra Taal or the 'Moon Lake' is a small lake (about 4km in circumference) located in the Himachal Pradesh state of India. While not as big as the lakes in Ladakh, ChandraTal is definitely one of the most beautiful lakes I have seen. 

Because of its small size the water in the lake is perfectly still when there is no wind. The entire lake is like a well polished mirror reflecting the peaks and glaciers of the magnificent Chandra - Bhaga mountain range. I camped for 2 days next to the lake to capture these time-lapse images.

title: First snowfall in Manali - Winter 2017
description:
A short video of the 2017 winter season's first snowfall in Manali. 

It has been a very long wait for this year's snowfall in Manali. The last rainfall in Manali was way back in August 2016 and then it has been a prolonged dry spell in Manali and the neighbouring villages. Forest fires were common during the autumn season and even a few house caught fire during the dry spell.

The local villagers were worried that it would be a repeat of the 2016 winter with very little snowfall. But thankfully all their prayers were answered and it started raining on July 6th. Raining mind you in January. Usually it snows here by the end of November. But the ground here was so dry and hot that it rained for one whole day before the snow started falling in the evening. And like they say, when it rains it pours. And it snowed and snowed and snowed. Almost 3 foot of snow over 3 days.

I made this short video while going to catch a bus to Delhi. The roads were slick with snow and buses and cars started slipping and going off the road. So instead of starting in Manali all the tourist buses started from Pathlikul, around 25km from Manali. I walked for 5 hours and rode in a car for 2 hours before finally catching my bus to Delhi!.

title: My Winter Camping Trips in Spiti
description:
A collection of moments from my winter hikes across Spiti in 2018. 

WARNING:
Please note that winter hiking in Spiti could be extremely dangerous due to heavy snowfall and avalanches. I planned my hikes around summer hamlets called Dogris which are located at a short distance (5 to 10km) from the villages and are safe from avalanches. And the villagers also regularly visit these hamlets during winters to clear snow from the roof of their summer homes. So there is a clear trail to these places. 

Also I always checked the weather forecast before venturing out. Please follow all safety precautions and check the latest rules and regulations with the local authorities before heading out.

title: Tsokar Lake - A Ladakh, India Timelapse
description:
A timelapse journey of Tsokar Lake in Ladakh, India.

Tso(lake) - Kar(salt) literally translates into 'Salt Lake' and it is one of the 3 high altitude (salt) lakes in Ladakh.

The Tsokar lake has less water compared to the Pangong and Tsomoriri lakes, but it makes up for it by the sheer expanse of wetlands and marshes that surround the lake. In my opinion this is the most interesting of all the lakes in Ladakh and i hope that my video would go some way towards shoring up my opinion.

title: Chamurthi Horses of Pin Valley
description:
The Chamurthi or Chhumurthi is a special breed of Himalayan pony native to the Pin Valley. The residents of Pin valley breed these horses and sell them at the annual Lavi Mela festival at Rampur.

During summers these horses are allowed to roam free in the mountains. But they are supervised by a couple of herders from the village who round up the horses every day into a large pen to ensure that predators do not attack the young foals. I found the entire process of rearing these horse very interesting and currently collecting footage to make a short film about it. This video can be considered as a preview of what is to come.
